SourceText: Remember that you’re in charge of what they eat, but not how much. Newborns have stomach the size of a grape! They need to eat often (sometimes in the middle of the night). It’s important to build trust around eating, especially as your baby starts on solid food. Let them know you are listening to their wishes in the eating department. They’ll be ravenous again soon!

SourceText: Have you been able to use consequences for not following instructions or forgetting household rules with your child or teen? How has it been?
text: Have you been able to use consequences for not following instructions or forgetting household rules with your child or teen? How has it been?

SourceText: Wonderful! When you are able to stay calm, give your child a choice to follow an instruction, and follow through with fair a consequence, you teach your child responsibilities for their actions. Keep it up!
text: Wonderful! When you are able to stay calm, give your child a choice to follow an instruction, and follow through with fair a consequence, you teach your child responsibilities for their actions. Keep it up!

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage well. This can be really difficult so be patient with yourself.
text: Sorry you did not manage well. This can be really difficult so be patient with yourself.

SourceText: What was difficult about using consequences?
text: What was difficult about using consequences?

SourceText: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.
text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

SourceText: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!
text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!

SourceText: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.
text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.

SourceText: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

SourceText: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.
text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.

SourceText: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!
text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

SourceText: Have you noticed and shared emotions with your child or teen recently? How did it make you feel?
text: Have you noticed and shared emotions with your child or teen recently? How did it make you feel?

SourceText: Amazing to hear it made you feel good, keep up the great work. Your child is learning so much from you!
text: Amazing to hear it made you feel good, keep up the great work. Your child is learning so much from you!

SourceText: Noticing and sharing emotions can be difficult at first, but you and your child or teen will get used to it. Keep trying and you will see the positive change!
text: Noticing and sharing emotions can be difficult at first, but you and your child or teen will get used to it. Keep trying and you will see the positive change!

SourceText: What was difficult for you about sharing emotions with your child or teen?
text: What was difficult for you about sharing emotions with your child or teen?

SourceText: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

SourceText: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.

SourceText: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

SourceText: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.
text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.

SourceText: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

SourceText: Have you been able to ignore your child's tantrums or other negative demanding behaviours? How has it been?
text: Have you been able to ignore your child's tantrums or other negative demanding behaviours? How has it been?

SourceText: Well done! Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. Good for you for giving it a try and being consistent!
text: Well done! Ignoring negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours is not easy. Good for you for giving it a try and being consistent!

SourceText: Sorry you did not manage well. Ignoring our children's whining or tantrums is really hard. Please be patient with yourself.
text: Sorry you did not manage well. Ignoring our children's whining or tantrums is really hard. Please be patient with yourself.

SourceText: What was difficult about using ignore?
text: What was difficult about using ignore?

SourceText: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!
text: I know, it can be really difficult to stay calm when our children are whining or having a tantrum. Try to think of something that you can do to help like taking a pause. You can do this!

SourceText: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!
text: If you are finding that you are ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, then your child is probably not getting enough positive attention at other times. Try to spend more One-on-One Time with your child!

SourceText: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.
text: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.

SourceText: I know, it is hard to be consistent! If you ignore a behaviour only some of the time, your child will think it might help them get their way. The more consistent you are, the less they will do it.
text: I know, it is hard to be consistent! If you ignore a behaviour only some of the time, your child will think it might help them get their way. The more consistent you are, the less they will do it.

SourceText: How are you doing with giving your child or teen instructions?
text: How are you doing with giving your child or teen instructions?

SourceText: Great to hear it went well, you are a star!
text: Great to hear it went well, you are a star!

SourceText: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!
text: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!

SourceText: What was your main challenge?
text: What was your main challenge?

SourceText: I know, our children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!
text: I know, our children need time to learn to follow instructions. Be patient, try again, and remember to praise them every time they follow an instruction!

SourceText: I know, it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it’s really worth trying again! Think about behaviour you would love to see your teen do more, and think of positive ways to give that instruction!
text: I know, it takes some time to get used to giving positive instructions – it’s really worth trying again! Think about behaviour you would love to see your teen do more, and think of positive ways to give that instruction!

SourceText: I know, it is hard to remember to give one instruction at a time. When we do it, our child is more likely to listen – so we can praise them even more!
text: I know, it is hard to remember to give one instruction at a time. When we do it, our child is more likely to listen – so we can praise them even more!

SourceText: Sometimes we just expect our children to do what we want them. But when we praise them for it, they feel encouraged to listen again next time!
text: Sometimes we just expect our children to do what we want them. But when we praise them for it, they feel encouraged to listen again next time!

SourceText: It is hard to remember to give realistic instructions. Try to make sure that your child or teen can physically do what you want them to do. Be specific!
text: It is hard to remember to give realistic instructions. Try to make sure that your child or teen can physically do what you want them to do. Be specific!

SourceText: Hi! How are you doing with treating your partner as an equal by, for example, involving them when making decisions?
text: Hi! How are you doing with treating your partner as an equal by, for example, involving them when making decisions?

SourceText: Sorry to hear this was difficult for you. Good job for trying!
text: Sorry to hear this was difficult for you. Good job for trying!

SourceText: What did you find difficult when learning to involve your partner and treat them as an equal?
text: What did you find difficult when learning to involve your partner and treat them as an equal?

SourceText: It can be difficult to find the time to ask our partners for their opinions when we are making decisions. Can you think of a time during the day when both you and your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening?
text: It can be difficult to find the time to ask our partners for their opinions when we are making decisions. Can you think of a time during the day when both you and your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening?

SourceText: It can be hard to remember to involve our partners in decision making. If you forget, it’s important to try again! Asking them for their opinion shows them that you care and want them to be involved.
text: It can be hard to remember to involve our partners in decision making. If you forget, it’s important to try again! Asking them for their opinion shows them that you care and want them to be involved.

SourceText: Sorry to hear that your partner reacted negatively. Be proud of yourself for trying and be gentle with yourself. Remember you can always get extra support by typing "Help".
text: Sorry to hear that your partner reacted negatively. Be proud of yourself for trying and be gentle with yourself. Remember you can always get extra support by typing "Help".

SourceText: It can take time to get used to making decisions together. Give yourself time to adjust. Remember that by communicating with your partner and involving them in decision-making, they will start to feel more comfortable doing so too.
text: It can take time to get used to making decisions together. Give yourself time to adjust. Remember that by communicating with your partner and involving them in decision-making, they will start to feel more comfortable doing so too.

SourceText: It can sometimes be hard to know how to involve your partner when making a decision. Sometimes all you need to do is to ask them what they think. This shows them you care and want them to be involved!
text: It can sometimes be hard to know how to involve your partner when making a decision. Sometimes all you need to do is to ask them what they think. This shows them you care and want them to be involved!

SourceText: Hi! How are you doing with getting involved in helping out at home as well as involving your partner in helping you with caregiving or housework?
text: Hi! How are you doing with getting involved in helping out at home as well as involving your partner in helping you with caregiving or housework?

SourceText: Fantastic, wonderful to hear that it went well!
text: Fantastic, wonderful to hear that it went well!

SourceText: Sorry to hear it was challenging. Well done for trying!
text: Sorry to hear it was challenging. Well done for trying!

SourceText: What did you find difficult when learning to become a confident parent and supportive partner?
text: What did you find difficult when learning to become a confident parent and supportive partner?

SourceText: Sometimes it can be hard to find time during the day. Can you think of a time when you’re less busy? For example, maybe it is easier to help out with housework later in the evening when some of the children have gone to sleep. Try to see what works for you!
text: Sometimes it can be hard to find time during the day. Can you think of a time when you’re less busy? For example, maybe it is easier to help out with housework later in the evening when some of the children have gone to sleep. Try to see what works for you!

SourceText: Be kind to yourself - trying something new is often hard at first! Give yourself time to adjust. Also remind yourself that helping your partner with these tasks benefits the whole family!
text: Be kind to yourself - trying something new is often hard at first! Give yourself time to adjust. Also remind yourself that helping your partner with these tasks benefits the whole family!

SourceText: Ask your child! By asking your child what their favourite activity is, you are showing them you care. Soon they might also start asking you to join them when they’re playing!
text: Ask your child! By asking your child what their favourite activity is, you are showing them you care. Soon they might also start asking you to join them when they’re playing!

SourceText: Ask them! By telling your partner you want to help out but don’t know how, you are showing them you care and are interested in being involved. This can also help family members understand each other better.
text: Ask them! By telling your partner you want to help out but don’t know how, you are showing them you care and are interested in being involved. This can also help family members understand each other better.

SourceText: It can be difficult to remember to ask others what they need help with. Once you start offering to help however, others may realise you want to be involved and may ask for help when they need it!
text: It can be difficult to remember to ask others what they need help with. Once you start offering to help however, others may realise you want to be involved and may ask for help when they need it!

SourceText: It can be hard to ask for help. Sometimes we expect our partners to know we need help even if we don’t ask them. Once you start telling however, they will likely start offering to help more often in the future.
text: It can be hard to ask for help. Sometimes we expect our partners to know we need help even if we don’t ask them. Once you start telling however, they will likely start offering to help more often in the future.

SourceText: How are you doing with sharing family responsibilities at home?
text: How are you doing with sharing family responsibilities at home?

SourceText: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Good job for trying!
text: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Good job for trying!

SourceText: What was difficult for you about sharing family responsibilities?
text: What was difficult for you about sharing family responsibilities?

SourceText: This can be hard to remember! Establishing a routine around caregiving or housework tasks can sometimes be helpful. This also lets you talk to your partner or other adults about how to share the workload.
text: This can be hard to remember! Establishing a routine around caregiving or housework tasks can sometimes be helpful. This also lets you talk to your partner or other adults about how to share the workload.

SourceText: Talk to them! Talking with your partner about how you can share family responsibilities helps both of you understand each other better. It also shows that you care!
text: Talk to them! Talking with your partner about how you can share family responsibilities helps both of you understand each other better. It also shows that you care!

SourceText: It is hard to remember to ask for help. Be kind to yourself if you forget to ask and try again another time. Asking for help and sharing family responsibilities benefits the whole family!
text: It is hard to remember to ask for help. Be kind to yourself if you forget to ask and try again another time. Asking for help and sharing family responsibilities benefits the whole family!

SourceText: It can be difficult to know how to ask for help. Try starting off with suggesting a task you would like help with. Being specific gives your partner a clearer idea of what they can support you with.
text: It can be difficult to know how to ask for help. Try starting off with suggesting a task you would like help with. Being specific gives your partner a clearer idea of what they can support you with.

SourceText: Trying something new can be hard! To make it easier, ask your partner to do it together with you the first few times. Soon you’ll feel more confident doing it on your own!
text: Trying something new can be hard! To make it easier, ask your partner to do it together with you the first few times. Soon you’ll feel more confident doing it on your own!

SourceText: It can be difficult to find time during the day sometimes! Can you think of a time when your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening? Creating a routine around housework can also be helpful.
text: It can be difficult to find time during the day sometimes! Can you think of a time when your partner might be less busy, such as early in the morning or later in the evening? Creating a routine around housework can also be helpful.

SourceText: Sharing responsibilities in the home benefits everyone! While trying something new can feel hard at first, soon you will start to feel more comfortable. If it helps, ask your partner to join you in the beginning!
text: Sharing responsibilities in the home benefits everyone! While trying something new can feel hard at first, soon you will start to feel more comfortable. If it helps, ask your partner to join you in the beginning!

SourceText: How are you doing with trying to resolve conflict in a calm way even when you feel frustrated?
text: How are you doing with trying to resolve conflict in a calm way even when you feel frustrated?

SourceText: What was difficult for you about resolving conflict peacefully?
text: What was difficult for you about resolving conflict peacefully?

SourceText: It can be really hard to stay calm when we’re having a disagreement with others. Try to think of something that you can do that might help like taking a couple deep breaths.
text: It can be really hard to stay calm when we’re having a disagreement with others. Try to think of something that you can do that might help like taking a couple deep breaths.

SourceText: By taking a pause before responding, it can help us stay calm and respond better. When you feel yourself getting angry, try taking a pause. You can do this!
text: By taking a pause before responding, it can help us stay calm and respond better. When you feel yourself getting angry, try taking a pause. You can do this!

SourceText: It can be easy to forget, but don’t give up! Next time when you start feeling angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. You can also try walking away for a bit if you start feeling frustrated.
text: It can be easy to forget, but don’t give up! Next time when you start feeling angry, try taking a deep breath before responding. You can also try walking away for a bit if you start feeling frustrated.

SourceText: Sometimes others respond to us negatively when we’re having a disagreement. In these situations, it is sometimes best to walk away for a bit until those involved have calmed down.
text: Sometimes others respond to us negatively when we’re having a disagreement. In these situations, it is sometimes best to walk away for a bit until those involved have calmed down.

SourceText: How are you doing with trying to talk to your partner about your feelings and any difficulties you’re facing?
text: How are you doing with trying to talk to your partner about your feelings and any difficulties you’re facing?

SourceText: What was hard for you when talking about your feelings and challenges you are facing?
text: What was hard for you when talking about your feelings and challenges you are facing?

SourceText: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.
text: Sharing how we feel and talking about the difficulties we’re facing actually makes everyone in the family stronger! By sharing emotions you can better understand and support each other.

SourceText: Starting something new can be difficult. Give yourself and others time to get used to it. By setting a good example by sharing your emotions and challenges you’re facing, others will feel start to feel more comfortable sharing too.
text: Starting something new can be difficult. Give yourself and others time to get used to it. By setting a good example by sharing your emotions and challenges you’re facing, others will feel start to feel more comfortable sharing too.

SourceText: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.
text: Sharing your emotions or difficulties you are facing is about making others more aware of how you are feeling. You get to decide how much you want to share. You can also choose to share more at a later time.

SourceText: It’s okay if you don’t want to share at that time. You can choose to share how you’re feeling at a later time once you feel calmer.
text: It’s okay if you don’t want to share at that time. You can choose to share how you’re feeling at a later time once you feel calmer.

SourceText: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing, can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life, and learning how to handle these, can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.
text: Talking about our feelings or challenges we’re facing, can help others understand and support you better. Emotions and challenges are a part of life, and learning how to handle these, can help you avoid conflict with loved ones and make life less stressful.

SourceText: Family and friends might tell you how a partner or a parent should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.

SourceText: All adults have disagreements sometimes. But solving issues through fighting is not effective. Instead, if you start feeling angry, walk away for a bit or take a deep breath before responding in a calmer way.

SourceText: Let your hand hang by your side. As you breathe in, squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears, scrunch your eyes and face, and hold your breath. Release your breath and then relax your shoulders and body.

SourceText: Quick tip: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.
text: Quick tip: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.

SourceText: Quick tip: All children misbehave. One thing that can help is to praise your child anytime that they do something good – however small. They may not look like they want your praise but they still really, really do.
text: Quick tip: All children misbehave. One thing that can help is to praise your child anytime that they do something good – however small. They may not look like they want your praise but they still really, really do.

SourceText: Quick tip: Caring for yourself is really important. Take five deep breaths when you feel overwhelmed. Try talking to a friend, or doing something relaxing for yourself? You deserve it!
text: Quick tip: Caring for yourself is really important. Take five deep breaths when you feel overwhelmed. Try talking to a friend, or doing something relaxing for yourself? You deserve it!

SourceText: Quick tip: Spending time with your child is free and even 5 minutes a day can make a difference. Try asking your child what they would like to do together. It can be fun and relaxing for you too!
text: Quick tip: Spending time with your child is free and even 5 minutes a day can make a difference. Try asking your child what they would like to do together. It can be fun and relaxing for you too!

SourceText: Quick tip: When you give your baby your full attention, you make them feel secure and loved. Try to spend at least 20 minutes a day playing with your baby. Switch off the television and put away phones. Make it fun!

SourceText: Quick tip: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: Quick tip: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.

SourceText: Quick tip: This is a stressful time for all of us. When a problem comes up, talk about it together! What is the problem exactly? What different solutions are there and what are the consequences of one? That way, you can find a solution that can be OK for everyone.
text: Quick tip: This is a stressful time for all of us. When a problem comes up, talk about it together! What is the problem exactly? What different solutions are there and what are the consequences of one? That way, you can find a solution that can be OK for everyone.
